{{Use dmy dates|date=November 2012}} {{one source|date=September 2011}} {{refimprove|date=September 2011}} '''Sir William Keith of [[Galston, East Ayrshire|Galston]]''' (d.1336) was a [[Kingdom of Scotland|Scottish]] Knight who fought in the [[Wars of Scottish Independence]].
==Life== Keith was the son of Robert de Keith, and grandson of [[John de Keith]] [[Earl Marischal|King's Marischal]].
Keith was in command of troops under [[James Douglas, Lord of Douglas|Sir James Douglas]] at the [[Capture of Berwick (1318)|Capture of Berwick]] in 1318.
Upon the death of [[Robert I of Scotland]] in 1329 he accompanied Sir James Douglas on crusade in Spain, with the King's embalmed heart. He was one of the few survivors of Douglas's party of knights and men-at-arms who survived the [[Battle of Teba]]. He was responsible for returning the King's heart and Douglas' bones and heart to Scotland, where the King's heart was buried at Melrose, and Douglas's remains solemnly interred in the [[kirk]] of St Bride in [[Douglas, South Lanarkshire|Douglas]].
He was in command at Berwick again in 1333 when the disastrous [[England|English]] victory at [[Battle of Halidon Hill|Halidon Hill]] took place.
In 1335 Keith was an ambassador to England, and in 1336 he was fighting at the [[Siege of Stirling Castle]], where he was killed.
==Issue== William Keith had a daughter:
*Janet Keith, married 1st [[David Hamilton of Cadzow]]; married 2nd [[Alexander Stewart of Darnley (d.1404)|Alexander Stewart of Darnley]].<ref>[https://archive.org/stream/genealogicalhera00inburk#page/2/mode/2up Burkes, p.2]</ref>
